title: Uninhabited
body:
You think you know everything about why Antarctica is uninhabitable: It's too cold for humans and for growing crops, it's dry as hell which is why it's classified as a desert, and it gets constant daytime and nighttime for weeks and even months during the winter and summer in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres respectively.

While that may be true, there is a whole other reason why Antarctica is not suitable for human life: the Inhabitant.

I worked at a research station in the western base of the Larsen Ice Shelf, a few thousand miles from the Falkland Islands in lower South America.

The closest other human being was in the eastern base of the Larsen Ice Shelf. She was a woman in about her late twenties or early thirties. Her name is S-4. We've grown very close together over the past 3 months we've been stationed here, even though we never met in person. Our bond, however would be cut short.

It was Day 88 here in Antarctica, only twelve days until me and S-4 are dismissed. I was supposed to run tests on the wind, ground, air pressure, climate, etc. I was a climatologist. S-4 researched the sky, clouds, meteors, Southern Lights, etc. She was a meteorologist. Anyway, at 3:00am PT she radioed me...

"S-2? S-2, come in. Over." S-2 means Station 2, my codename referring to my assigned station. Her station was Station 4.

A little irritated about being woken up early in the morning, I got out of my cot and shuffled over to the radio.

"S-4, what is it?", I sleepily croaked. "It had better be important enough to justify you waking me up at..." I checked the clock, "3:00 in the morning... Over."

"Quit whining and look out your window, S-2. Over", she replied. This was basically our relationship during our time stationed here: sass and banter, back and forth. It hasn't bothered me or her, so it works out.

I turned the lamp on and slowly walked towards the window, still waking up. I rolled up the blinds and found... nothing. Just a sad, white, barren landscape in the dark of night.

"Very funny, S-4. I hope it was worth it waking me up for a good laugh. Over", I said with a subtle hint of sarcasm.

"Look above you, dummy. Over.", She replied with the tone of sarcasm in her soft voice daring to challenge mine.

I did so. What I saw made the living conditions of my job entirely worth it. That, and talking with S-4.

It was a meteor shower, a damn pretty one at that. S-4, being the meteorologist, would've killed to see something like this. I could see why she would wake me for this.

"Holy shit... Over", I spoke into the radio.

"Holier-than-thou shit. Over." She was always the expert of banter.

"Ha-ha."

A few seconds passed before S-4 said, "S-2 you gotta say 'over' after you say something in the radio. Over."

Feeling a good round of Sass and Banter coming up, I remarked, "I have to say what, S-4? Over."

S-4 quickly caught on. We were experienced in this. "You have to say the word 'over', S-2. Over."

"S-4, I think your signal is weakening. Could you please repeat that? Over."

"The word, in quotations, 'ov'--... What the fuck?"

At first I almost thought she was fucking with me, but the seriousness in her voice made me think otherwise. She never spoke in a serious tone whenever she was joking. Never.

A pause. "...S-4? W-what's wrong?.. Over."

Another pause. "...S-4, please respond. Over."

A final pause. "...Station 4, what's happening?"

I worried so much that I forgot to say "over".

She finally picked up. "What--Oh! Yeah, yeah. Sorry, S-2. Just... look to the east, will you?"

I looked to the direction of her station. I couldn't see anything for a moment before a bright blue light shone over the horizon. It was almost like a flare.

Before I could say anything to S-4, the station shook violently. It lasted no more than ten seconds before it ceased. It could've been an earthquake, but knew better. The meteor shower, the bright light near Station 4, then the quaking were just all too... connected to be a coincidence.

I took the chance to speak, "Did you feel that too, S-4? Over."

A few moments passed before she replied, "-tion 2, you there? Over."

"Yeah. I said did you feel that? Over."

"Yeah, I did. It was much closer to me. I think the quakes temporarily knocked out my comms, but I managed to get them back online. Over"

I struggled to find the words, so I settled on, "I don't think those were quakes, S-4. Over."

"Me neither. Over."

"You said it was closer to you, right? Then it hit me a few seconds after you? Over."

"...Yeah. You're suggesting those were shock waves? Over."

"Exactly. Over."

A moment passed, "Hmm, I'll see what S-3 has to say about this. In the meantime, you can go back to bed. Over."

"I'm already wide awake now after that. Over."

"Hah."

She forgot to say "over". I wasn't in the mood for another round of Sass and Banter. "Right. So... In the meantime. Over."

"In the meantime... Over."

Day 90, ten days until dismissal. It was about evening from what I could tell. About fifteen miles south was a snowstorm heading our way. Because of that, I've had to conduct research like there was no tomorrow. How ironic.

After what felt like an eternity, S-4 radioed me, "Afternoon, Station 2. Over."

I picked up the radio, "Hey, S-4. Did you get any feedback from S-3? Over."

"I did indeed. He told me the shockwave hit him after me, and before you. So the epicenter of the blast is definitely closest to me. He also told me a whole chunk of ice about a quarter-mile wide was melted by the impact. Over."

"You're safe though, right? Over."

"Yes, I'm fine, S-2. No need to worry about me... Another thing, there's been a sort of flare-like smoke billowing from the site for about... 38 hours now.

I took that chance to glance at the clock. It said 3:00am... That was impossible... Unless...

"S-4, it says 3:00am on my clock. What does it say on yours? Over."

"3:00am? Shit, uhh... It says 1:00am on my clock... O-over."

"Shit, our clocks were fucked up by the shockwave. Check in with Station 3 and see if his clock is fucked up too."

We both forgot to say "over" from then on. A couple minutes passed. The storm gradually got closer and closer. Antigone picked up again, "Alright, S-3 says his clock is fucked up as well."

I contemplated that for a moment, "Shit. W-what about Main Base?" Main Base was at the edge of the Larsen Ice Shelf, 100 miles away from us.

She yelled in a panicked voice, "I tried them, and I couldn't get a hold of them! Our comms are down! The only reason we can talk to each other is because we're connected by cables and wires!"

"Well what the fuck are we supposed to do?"

"I don't know, just-- We'll stay here, okay? They're probably working comms maintenance at Main Base. So I'm sure we'll be fine if we just wait it out."

Famous last words.

Day 91, or so I thought. It could've still been Day 90 or Day 93 for fuck's sake. Our clocks were still off because of our lack of communication with Main Base, so we can't be sure exactly what time it is. The snowstorm came overnight. There was nothing but darkness and fast-falling snow outside. It was freezing inside too, which makes it a real bitch to focus on my research of the storm. I guessed it was about early morning. A couple hours into my research, a male voice I hadn't heard in a long time sounded from the radio. I knew who it was. It was Station 3.

His voice had a sense of dread and urgency in it, "Stations 2 and 4, please pick up the radio. It's urgent. Over."

I was the first to respond, "Station 2 here. What is it S-3? Over."

"S-2, good. Station 4, are you there? Over."

A couple seconds passed before S-4 answered, "I'm here, S-3. What seems to be the problem? Over."

S-3 responded, "S-2 and 4. Good. I've been observing the activity of the meteor impact site, and it's just-- well-- fuck, I don't know how to explain it!"

"S-3, calm down and tell us what exactly did you see?" I asked him.

He sounded scared shitless, "Well, f-first there was a red glow coming from the site. It was so intense, that it was glowing through the ice... Then th-there was this one f-figure slowly emerging from the epicenter. It wasn't walking or moving or--or anything! It was just fucking floating!"

S-4 responded, "S-3, can you describe what the figure looked like?"

"It--it looked like a human, I mean it had the shape of a human, but... that's about it. It was so... so fucking huge... like a fucking tower... And it h-had a big red, glowing dot on its face, like a spotlight."

"S-3, where is it now?" I asked him.

A pause, "...Umm, hold on... Oh--oh no...", he said in a hushed voice.

"What is it?", S-4 asked.

"S-4, lock all your doors and windows and shut all the blinds! You do so as well, S-2!" He was now permanently panicked.

"What?! Why?"

"It's heading towards you!"

That caught us all by surprise. That... thing, whatever it was, was heading towards Station 4. I couldn't imagine what it would do when it got there. I wanted so desperately to help, to do anything, but I couldn't. I was trapped in my Station. So was Station 3. So was Station 4.

There was a sound of clattering coming from the radio. I assumed S-4 dropped hers in the rush to lock herself in her Station. We all followed suit.

S-4 picked up again, "Okay, I've done it. W-what now?" She was just as afraid as the rest of us.

S-3 quickly responded, "Turn off your radio! Destroy it if you have to! That... creature might hear you!"

S-4 started crying. I couldn't blame her. "I don't want to be alone... I'm scared. I'm scared. I'm sc--"

A dreadful pause echoed through the radio. I whispered, "...S-4, what's happening?"

I could hear S-4 trying her best to contain her crying, but it was futile. She whispered back, "...There's a beam... A red beam of light encircling my Station..."

S-3 whispered after another dreadful pause, "Station 4, don't. Fucking. Move."

She didn't respond.

"S-4?" He said.

A pause.

S-3 gasped, "Oh, no. No, no, no, no, no, no. Please, God, no."

"S-3, what happened?" I asked with more dread than I could bear.

No amount of words could describe what I felt after I heard Station 3 say the words, "Station 2... Station 4... is gone. It just... disintegrated in an instant."

".....What?"

Twenty minutes passed without him answering until he finally said, "Oh shit. No, no! No, no , no!!! FUCK!"

I didn't have to ask to know what was happening. I grabbed my binoculars and peaked through the window blinds facing east. In the horizon, I saw Station 3. And even further away, I saw what S-3 had been talking about: the upper torso of the large, human shaped figure the size of a goddamn tower with a glowing crimson circle where the face should've been, like a spotlight.

I dropped my radio, S-3 still begging for mercy from the tower to no avail. I didn't want to watch, yet I couldn't take my eyes off the scene. The tower's blood-red spotlight shone over Station 3 and, after half a minute, left absolutely nothing of Station 3. No debris, no dust, no ashes, nothing.

I was too horrified to move until the red spotlight pointed directly at me. I yelped and fell backwards. It would be at least thirty minutes before the tower reached my Station. I crawled into the corner, trying to find the words to describe my fear, my hope that this was just a nightmare, but deep down I knew... it wasn't.

end of transmission

I'm done listening to the recording of the last three-four days, reminiscing my time here, with S-4. Now those days have been obliterated. It's been about fifty minutes since Station 3 was destroyed, and I'm still waiting for my turn.

That just may come soon, as a see a very faint glow of red, shining through the blinds, getting more and more intense as time passes. The more intense the glow gets, the more I hear a sort of electrical humming sound. Now a shadow has passed through the glow and the blinds. I know... that in a few moments, this will all be over...

Over.
author: Breezydeau
